revision.comment: /* List of 107% rule violations */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} The '''107% rule''' is a sporting regulation affecting [[Formula One]] racing [[Formula One racing#Qualifying sessions|qualifying sessions]]. During the first phase of qualifying, any driver who fails to set a lap within 107 percent of the fastest time in the first qualifying session will not be allowed to start the race without permission from the race stewards. For example, if the fastest Q1 lap time was 60 seconds, each driver must complete at least one lap within 64.2 seconds to guarantee a start. The 107% rule was introduced for the {{F1|1996}} season and remained in force until {{F1|2002}}. It was reintroduced for the {{F1|2011}} season with minor modifications due to the knock-out qualifying format.
==History== {{quote box | align = left | width = 100% | quote = Unless the track was declared wet by the race director, any driver eliminated during Q1 whose best qualifying lap exceeds 107% of the fastest time set during that session, or who fails to set a time, will not be allowed to take part in the race. Under exceptional circumstances however, which may include setting a suitable lap time in a free practice session, the stewards may permit the car to start the race.
Any driver accepted in this manner will be placed at the back of the starting grid after any other penalties have been applied.
Should there be more than one driver accepted in this manner they will be arranged on the grid in the order they were classified in P3.
- Article 35.1 of the 2018 Formula One Sporting Regulations<ref>https://www.fia.com/file/70710/download/23276?token=szOjLZMY</ref> | source = }} {{clear}} ===Introduction=== The governing body of F1, the [[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]] (FIA), introduced the 107% rule at a meeting of its [[FIA World Motor Sport Council|World Motor Sport Council]] in June 1995, immediately prior to the [[1995 French Grand Prix|French Grand Prix]].<ref>{{cite news| title =World Council decisions| publisher =grandprix.com| url =http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns00196.html| date =3 July 1995| accessdate =3 January 2009}}</ref> This followed a recommendation from the [[Formula One Commission]], a working group of F1 representatives, to introduce such a measure.<ref name=ASTS>{{cite journal|last=Dodgins|first=Tony|date=29 June 1995|title=Top Story: F1 grid cut threatens small teams|journal=[[Autosport]]|volume=139|issue=13|pages=4–5}}</ref> Over the previous few years, the number of entries per season had dropped to 26, the maximum threshold for race starters, allowing every entrant to qualify for the race regardless of speed. For {{F1|1995}}, new technical regulations spaced out the field, whilst numerous teams with comparatively small budgets and slow cars, such as [[Forti]], [[Pacific Racing|Pacific]] and [[Simtek]], were competing in the sport. The regulation was originally planned to come into effect from the [[1995 Hungarian Grand Prix]], but this required unanimous support amongst the teams, and was vetoed by Forti and Pacific. Nevertheless, the fact that it was supported by the majority of the teams allowed the 107% rule's introduction from the start of the {{F1|1996}} season.<ref name=ASTS/> The mid 1990s also brought a number of [[pay driver]]s to the sport whose speeds would not have allowed one to race, such as [[Giovanni Lavaggi]] and [[Jean-Denis Délétraz]].
Commenting on the introduction of the 107% rule, FIA President [[Max Mosley]] said that "any small team which is properly organised will be able to get within the 107 per cent margin".<ref>Henry (ed.) (1995), p. 38.</ref> The sport's commercial rights holder, [[Bernie Ecclestone]], agreed with this sentiment, saying in an interview that "Formula 1 is the best. And we don't need anything in it that isn't the best." He also accused some of the smaller teams of having a "startline special" mentality, in that they were solely concerned with entering the race to gain television coverage for their sponsors, and were not too occupied with actual performance given that all the entrants were guaranteed to make the race.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roebuck|first=Nigel|authorlink=Nigel Roebuck|date=6 July 1995|title=Fifth Column: Never mind the width|journal=[[Autosport]]|volume=140|issue=1|page=25}}</ref> On the other hand, the smaller teams were concerned at the prospect of having to lap within a maximum time in order to qualify, which they saw as exacerbating the inequalities already existent within the sport. Pacific's commercial manager, [[Mark Gallagher]], said: "We have to say the 107% rule gives rise to concern among teams without [[List of motorsport terminology#W|works]] engines. It's got more to do with engines than chassis, and that's an area outside our direct capability. Closing the gap to [[Minardi]] is quite feasible, but the sudden arrival of the rule is worrying. If you have three years to plan whether or not to do something, that's very different from having the goalposts moved while you are playing the game."<ref name=ASTS/>
===Application=== The 107% rule was thus introduced at the [[1996 Australian Grand Prix]]. It was breached immediately, as [[Forti]] drivers [[Luca Badoer]] and [[Andrea Montermini]] failed to lap within 107% of [[Jacques Villeneuve]]'s pole position time. This had been an expected outcome, as the team was using an upgraded version of the previous year's [[Forti FG01]] chassis, which had only qualified within 107% of pole position on one of thirty-four occasions beforehand.<ref>Henry (ed.) (1996), pp. 92, 101.</ref> Both drivers also failed to qualify for the [[1996 European Grand Prix|European Grand Prix]], the fourth round of the championship. At the following race, the [[1996 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino Grand Prix]], Badoer drove the more competitive [[Forti FG03|FG03]] chassis for the first time, whilst Montermini failed to make the 107% cut in the older car.<ref>Henry (ed.) (1996), p. 136.</ref> Both then failed to qualify for the [[1996 Spanish Grand Prix|Spanish Grand Prix]] two races later. By the tenth round of the championship, the [[1996 British Grand Prix|British Grand Prix]], the team was running out of money and made only a token attempt to qualify after not taking part in the preceding free practice sessions, neither car making the time limit.<ref>Henry (ed.) (1996), pp. 92, 185.</ref> Following the next race, in which the team did not complete any laps at all, Forti withdrew from Formula One. In the latter half of the season, the [[Minardi]] team replaced regular driver [[Giancarlo Fisichella]] with the [[pay driver|paying]] [[Giovanni Lavaggi]], who failed to make the 107% cut at the [[1996 German Grand Prix|German]], [[1996 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian]] and [[1996 Japanese Grand Prix|Japanese]] Grands Prix.
In {{F1|1997}}, the 107% rule was only invoked at the season-opening [[1997 Australian Grand Prix|Australian Grand Prix]]. Villeneuve again set pole position with a time over a second faster than his nearest rival, resulting in a well-spaced field.<ref name="1997p107">Henry (ed.) (1997), p. 107.</ref> As a result, [[Pedro Diniz]], [[Vincenzo Sospiri]] and [[Ricardo Rosset]] all failed to make the 107% mark. Diniz was allowed to race at the discretion of the race stewards, who judged him capable of lapping within the limit, as he had indeed done so during the free practice session prior to qualifying.<ref name="1997p107"/><ref>Henry (ed.) (1997), p. 100.</ref> The FIA cited "exceptional circumstances" as the reason for his failure to do so during the qualifying session itself.<ref>{{cite news| title =F1 teams race home to test| publisher =grandprix.com| url =http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns01020.html| date =17 March 1997| accessdate =27 March 2009}}</ref> Sospiri and Rosset, driving for the new [[MasterCard Lola]] team, were, however, five and six seconds off Diniz's time respectively, and well outside the qualification limit.<ref name="1997p107"/> Neither driver was allowed to start the race, and the team folded before the next Grand Prix.
During the {{F1|1998}} season, Rosset—now driving for the [[Tyrrell Racing|Tyrrell]] team—failed to qualify on five occasions. He lapped outside the 107% time during qualifying sessions for the [[1998 Spanish Grand Prix|Spanish]], [[1998 Monaco Grand Prix|Monaco]], [[1998 Hungarian Grand Prix|Hungarian]] and [[1998 Japanese Grand Prix|Japanese]] Grands Prix. He also failed to qualify for the [[1998 German Grand Prix|German Grand Prix]], but this was due to him not completing any laps at all after injuring his right elbow as a result of a heavy crash during free practice.<ref>Henry (ed.) (1998), p. 192.</ref>
The 107% rule was invoked on two occasions in {{F1|1999}}. At the first round of the championship—the [[1999 Australian Grand Prix|Australian Grand Prix]]—[[Marc Gené]] failed to lap within the required percentage of the pole position time in his Minardi. As with Diniz two years earlier, he was given dispensation to race after lapping within the limit during the free practice sessions.<ref>Henry (ed.) (1999), p. 99.</ref> At the [[1999 French Grand Prix|French Grand Prix]] later in the season, a qualifying session marked by a varying intensity of rainfall saw five drivers—[[Damon Hill]], Gené, [[Luca Badoer]], [[Pedro de la Rosa]] and [[Toranosuke Takagi]]—miss the cut-off, but all were allowed to start the race.<ref>Henry (ed.) (1999), p. 149.</ref>
After a {{F1|2000}} season in which no driver transgressed the 107% rule, it was enforced on three occasions in {{F1|2001}}. At the opening race in [[2001 Australian Grand Prix|Australia]], [[Tarso Marques]] failed to lap within the required time for Minardi. He was given permission to race under the reason of "exceptional circumstances", but this was despite the fact that he had not managed to set a time within the 107% mark in any session all weekend.<ref>Henry (ed.) (2001), p. 115.</ref> It was rumoured that Marques was allowed to race because the team had been bought prior to the start of the season by Australian [[Paul Stoddart]], who wanted both cars to compete in Minardi's new "home" Grand Prix.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.grandprix.com/gpe/rr664.html |title=GRAND PRIX RESULTS: AUSTRALIAN GP, 2001 |accessdate=27 March 2009 |publisher=grandprix.com }}</ref> At the [[2001 British Grand Prix|British Grand Prix]], Marques again fell foul of the regulation, but was not allowed to start on this occasion.<ref>Henry (ed.) (2001), p. 198.</ref> The [[2001 Belgian Grand Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]] also witnessed a wet qualifying session in which the track steadily dried, resulting in the four slowest qualifiers—[[Jos Verstappen]], [[Fernando Alonso]], [[Enrique Bernoldi]] and Marques—failing to lap within 107% of pole position. As in the similar case of the French Grand Prix two years previously, all were allowed to start the race.<ref>Mansell (ed.), pp. 353, 379, 495.</ref>
[[File:Frentzen Bernoldi France 2002.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Arrows Grand Prix International|Arrows]] team deliberately failed to qualify for the [[2002 French Grand Prix]] due to financial problems.]]
The 107% rule also came into effect during the {{F1|2002}} season. At the first round of the championship, the [[2002 Australian Grand Prix|Australian Grand Prix]], [[Takuma Sato]] crashed heavily during free practice and had to use the [[Jordan Grand Prix|Jordan]] team's spare car for qualifying, only for the replacement to stop with a gearbox problem without setting a time. By the time his teammate, Fisichella, did his first run and handed over his own chassis, it had begun to rain, leaving Sato with no chance of making the required time. However, he was allowed to start the race as in the case of previous cases affected by changeable weather conditions.<ref>Henry (ed.) (2002), p. 91.</ref> Minardi driver [[Alex Yoong]] failed to qualify for the [[2002 San Marino Grand Prix|San Marino]], [[2002 British Grand Prix|British]] and [[2002 German Grand Prix|German]] Grands Prix under the conditions of the rule, a turn of events which led to his replacement by [[Anthony Davidson]] for two races.<ref>Henry (ed.) (2002), p. 81.</ref> At the [[2002 French Grand Prix|French Grand Prix]], the Arrows team was running out of money and made a token appearance during the qualifying session to avoid FIA-imposed fines for missing rounds of the championship; drivers [[Heinz-Harald Frentzen]] and Bernoldi failed to lap within the required time. Frentzen subsequently left the circuit with ten minutes of the session still remaining, making the team's ploy obvious.<ref name="2002p180">Henry (ed.) (2002), p. 180.</ref> Fisichella also failed to set a time during this session, although this was the result of his withdrawal from the event following a heavy crash during free practice.<ref name="2002p180"/>
In total, there were 37 cases in which 107% rule was broken during the period in which it was a Formula One Sporting Regulation. Of these, 13 drivers were allowed to start the relevant race due to "exceptional circumstances". The rule affected 23 out of the 116 Grands Prix in which it applied.
===Abolition=== The qualifying system changed for the {{F1|2003}} season with the introduction of two ordered single-lap sessions to replace the previous free hour-long session in which drivers were allowed to complete twelve laps. Drivers also had to qualify with the race fuel on board their cars. Due to the scope for greater time disparities throughout the field that could occur as a result, the 107% rule was not mentioned when the FIA finalised the format prior to the beginning of the season, despite an earlier assurance that the rule would still apply.<ref>{{cite news| title =FIA: 107% Rule is Still On for 2003| publisher =atlasf1.autosport.com| url =http://atlasf1.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/8918/.html| date =29 October 2002| accessdate =17 March 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =FIA clarifies F1 qualifying regulations| publisher =autosport.com| url =http://www.autosport-atlas.com/article.asp?id=22033| accessdate =17 March 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title =Qualifying format finalized| publisher =grandprix.com| url =http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns08697.html| date =26 February 2003| accessdate =17 March 2009}}</ref> The governing body subsequently proposed the formal cancellation of the rule,<ref>{{cite news| title =The 107% rule to be axed| publisher =grandprix.com| url =http://www.grandprix.com/ns/ns08703.html| date =27 February 2003| accessdate =17 March 2009}}</ref> which ceased to apply with effect from the [[2002 Japanese Grand Prix]].
Following the 2003 season, the timing of the two single-lap sessions was altered for them to occur on the same day, within 15 minutes of each other. This proved unpopular with the smaller teams, who were liable to make their runs at the end of the first session (as this was run in championship order) and at the beginning of the second session (which was run in reverse order of the results of the first session), and with TV spectators, who had to watch a longer programme as a result. During the {{F1|2004}} season, the system's flaws were exposed, and proposed changes to the qualifying system made midway through the championship at one point seemed to suggest that the 107% rule would return as part of a new format. In the end, however, only minor changes relating to the timing of the existing sessions were made.<ref>{{cite news| last=Baldwin| first=Alan| title =FIA and Teams Agree to Leave Qualifying As Is| publisher =atlasf1.autosport.com| url =http://atlasf1.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/13732/.html| date =28 June 2004| accessdate =17 March 2009}}</ref> [[Minardi]] team owner [[Paul Stoddart]] was particularly opposed to the reintroduction of the rule.<ref>{{cite news |last=Cameron |first=David |title=107% Rule Will Not be Reintroduced |publisher=atlasf1.autosport.com |url=http://atlasf1.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/13574/.html |date =13 June 2004 |accessdate=17 March 2009}}</ref>
===Reintroduction=== At the start of the {{F1|2010}} season, new FIA President [[Jean Todt]] said that he was in favour of re-introducing the 107% rule, as the qualifying system has changed again so that all of the sessions are carried out with low fuel levels.<ref>{{cite news|last=Noble|first=Jonathan|author2=Elizalde, Pablo|title=Todt in favour of 107 per cent rule|publisher=[[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publications]]|work=autosport.com|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/82045|date=12 March 2010|accessdate=12 March 2010}}</ref>
On 23 June, a meeting of the [[FIA World Motor Sport Council]] determined that the 107% rule would be reintroduced for the {{F1|2011}} season. The rule applies only to the first of the three qualifying sessions for each race.<ref>{{cite web |title=2011 F1 Sporting Regulations |publisher=[[Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile]] |url=http://argent.fia.com/web/fia-public.nsf/9A195FD4A47DA4E1C12577F8004AA63E/$FILE/1-2011%20SPORTING%20REGULATIONS%2010-12-2010.pdf |accessdate=29 March 2011}}</ref>
Since its re-introduction and till the end of the {{F1|2015}} season, the 107% rule has been broken a further 16 times at 11 different races, exclusively by [[HRT Formula 1 Team|HRT]], [[Caterham F1|Caterham]], and [[Virgin Racing|Virgin]]/[[Marussia F1|Marussia]] drivers. Unlike the rule's first period of application, where infringing drivers were very rarely allowed to compete, only four of these occurrences of the rule violation resulted in the drivers being barred from the race. These were [[Vitantonio Liuzzi]] and [[Narain Karthikeyan]] at the [[2011 Australian Grand Prix]], and [[Pedro de la Rosa]] and Karthikeyan at the [[2012 Australian Grand Prix]] – all of whom drove for HRT. At the [[2016 Hungarian Grand Prix]], 11 cars failed to reach the 107% limit as the session was stopped for inclement weather and subsequent incidents, but all were permitted to compete.

==Use in other formulae== The 107% rule has also been used in other motorsport formulae.
===GP2 Series=== It is currently in operation in the [[GP2 Series]], where it has been applied on three occasions. [[Marcos Martínez]] failed to qualify for his debut race meeting at the [[Hungaroring]] in [[2007 GP2 Series season|2007]] after failing to set a lap time due to engine problems, despite lapping within 107% of the fastest time in free practice.<ref>{{cite web|title=Martínez not allowed to debut in GP2 this weekend|publisher=GPUpdate|url=http://www.gpupdate.net/en/gp2-news/162167/martinez-not-allowed-to-debut-in-gp2-this-weekend/|date=7 August 2007|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> At the [[Circuit de Monaco|Monaco]] round of the [[2009 GP2 Series season|2009 season]], [[Ricardo Teixeira (racing driver)|Ricardo Teixeira]] failed to lap within 107% of the pole position time and was not allowed to take part in the races.<ref>{{cite web |title=Trident Racing's Davide Rigon, 9th while Ricardo Teixeira did not start |publisher=Automobilsport |work=automobilsport.com |url=http://www.automobilsport.com/teams-pilots--35,63749,Trident-Racings-Davide-Rigon-9th-while-Ricardo-Teixeira-did-not-start,news.htm |date=23 May 2009 |accessdate=24 July 2009 |author=Maggy Parries |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iZFDnvqi?url=http://www.automobilsport.com/teams-pilots--35,63749,Trident-Racings-Davide-Rigon-9th-while-Ricardo-Teixeira-did-not-start,news.htm |archivedate=27 July 2009 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> During qualifying for the round of the championship held at the Hungaroring later that year, [[Romain Grosjean]] and [[Franck Perera]] collided before either had set a representative lap time: Perera was judged guilty of impeding and was barred from taking part in the first race, but allowed to start from the back of the grid in the second; Grosjean was given dispensation to start both races.<ref>{{cite web|title=Franck Perera handed penalty |publisher=[[GP2 Series]] |work=gp2series.com |url=http://www.gp2series.com/en//website/2009gp2series/news/newsgp2/newsdetail.php?articleid=2457 |date=24 July 2009 |accessdate=24 July 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5iZFFKTEc?url=http://www.gp2series.com/en//website/2009gp2series/news/newsgp2/newsdetail.php?articleid=2457 |archivedate=27 July 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Perera also failed to qualify for the [[Circuit de Spa-Francorchamps|Spa-Francorchamps]] races under the 107% criteria.<ref>{{cite web|last=Glendenning |first=Mark |title=Di Grassi penalised for blocking |publisher=[[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publishing]] |work=autosport.com |url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/78085 |date=28 August 2009 |accessdate=19 September 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jxwpQrVC?url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/78085 |archivedate=22 September 2009 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
===GP3 Series=== The 107% rule is also used in the [[GP3 Series]]. So far, a driver has only failed to qualify on one occasion. In the [[2012 GP3 Series season|2012]] [[2012 Silverstone GP2 and GP3 Series rounds#GP3 Series classification|Silverstone round]], [[Carmen Jordá]] failed to set a lap time within 107% of the pole time. As she was also outside 107% of the fastest time in the practice session, she was not allowed to start the race.
===Super GT=== {{refimprove section|date=May 2011}}
In [[Super GT]] series, a slightly different 107% rule is being used. The base time was being calculated by averaging time of top three vehicles in their class rather than by taking pole position time. All drivers in the non-seeded team must finish within this time in order to qualify for the race. However, teams which could not qualify in official qualifying sessions, may still be allowed to retry in following day's practice session, providing reasons such as accidents. In this case, the 107% of top three cars in practice session's will be used instead, in return, they will start at the back of the grid. In race using knockout format, a separated qualifying will be launched prior the knockout qualifying to decide teams which are allowed to take part in the race.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://supergt.net/supergt/2010/10regulation/index.htm |title=2010 Super GT Regulations Digest |publisher=supergt.net |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928200747/http://supergt.net/supergt/2010/10regulation/index.htm |archivedate=28 September 2011}}</ref>
Another major difference of the 107% rule in Super GT is that there is a protection system called "seeded teams", which is awarded to each class's team which participated in all races and finished within top 12 in the previous season. "Seeded teams", provided they meet other entrance requirements, are allowed to participate in the race even when they have not met the qualifying time in official qualifying sessions. The right will be forfeited when the team switches class or withdraws from the series, the void caused by this will not be filled by other teams.

{{refimprove|date=August 2016}} {{Year box}} '''1802 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 20 August — [[James Belcher|Jem Belcher]] successfully defends his English title by defeating Joe Berks in 13 rounds at "Hanover Spa" in London.<ref name="JB">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/belcher-jem.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Belcher]. Retrieved on 7 November 2009.</ref>
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[E. H. Budd]] makes his debut in [[first-class cricket]]. '''England''' * Most runs<ref name="cards">Note that scorecards created in the first quarter of the 19th century are not necessarily accurate or complete; therefore any summary of runs, wickets or catches can only represent the '''known''' totals and the missing data prevents effective computation of averages</ref> – [[Lord Frederick Beauclerk]] 106 (HS 54) * Most wickets<ref name="cards"/> – [[Lord Frederick Beauclerk]] 7
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Tyrant (horse)|Tyrant]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Scotia * [[St Leger Stakes]] – [[Orville (horse)|Orville]]

revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1867 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[Football]]== '''England''' * Formation of the [[Sheffield FA]], which continues to promote its own [[Sheffield Rules]]. The Sheffield FA establishes the local [[Youdan Cup]], the first organised football tournament, which is won by [[Hallam F.C.|Hallam FC]]. * 4 September — [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|The Wednesday]] founded by members of [[the Wednesday Cricket Club]] in Sheffield. As is so often the case, a football club is founded by cricketers who need a winter activity to keep fit. The club name acknowledges that Wednesday was the day on which members take an afternoon off work for practice. The Wednesday is originally based at [[Bramall Lane]], then a multi–sports complex that had originally opened for cricket in 1854. '''Scotland''' * [[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]] founded in Glasgow; it is the oldest association football club in Scotland.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[National Association of Base Ball Players]] champion – [[Union of Morrisania]] '''Events''' * The National baseball club of Washington ([[Washington Nationals (NA)|original Washington Nationals]]) tours from Ohio to Missouri, playing ten matches in 17 days. Like the Excelsiors tour of New York state in 1860, the Nationals boost the game and demonstrate advanced points of play to fans and players. Several top teams will tour on a similar national scale in the next few years.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * Publication of the [[Marquess of Queensberry rules]] which had been written in 1865. These rules prescribe the use of gloves, the ten second count, the three minute round and the one minute's rest between rounds. * 10 May — [[Jimmy Elliott]] defeats [[Bill Davis (boxer)|Bill Davis]] in the 9th round at Point Pelee Island in Canada. Davis has now lost to both Elliott and [[Mike McCoole]] who continue to claim the American Championship, but these two will never meet in the ring.<ref name="JE">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/elliott.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jimmy Elliott]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 31 August — McCoole defeats [[Aaron Jones (boxer)|Aaron Jones]] in the 34th round at Busenbord's Station, Ohio.<ref name="MM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mccoole.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Mike McCoole]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * 15 October — [[Jem Mace]] is due to defend the English Championship against Ned O'Baldwin in London but the bout is prevented by the authorities. There is by this time considerable opposition to bareknuckle boxing in England and fights are becoming impossible to stage at all, let alone profitably. Mace reacts to the latest ban by taking his trade to America, leaving the English Championship as a dead title. Competitive boxing in Great Britain is effectively terminated until after the foundation of the [[National Sporting Club]] in 1891.<ref name="JM">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/mace-j.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Jem Mace]. Retrieved on 8 November 2009.</ref> * The demise of bareknuckle boxing in England is consistent with the spread of Victorian ethics and morality. The influential newspaper industry has fuelled distaste for prizefighting by widely publicising the brutality of the 1860 Heenan–Sayers fight. The Queensberry Rules with their demand for gloves and timings are an establishment reaction to the furore and are designed to "clean up" a sport that is out of touch with Victorian values.
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[George Wootton]]'s tally of 142 wickets breaks his own record for an English season '''England''' * Most runs – [[Thomas Humphrey]] 946 @ 26.27 (HS 144) * Most wickets – [[George Wootton]] 142 @ 11.58 (BB 8–15)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1867 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Tom Morris, Sr.|Tom Morris senior]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural running of the [[Belmont Stakes]] is won by [[Ruthless (horse)|Ruthless]] '''England''' * [[1867 Grand National|Grand National]] – Cortolvin * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Achievement (horse)|Achievement]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – Vauban * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Hermit (horse)|Hermit]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – Hippia * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Achievement '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Tim Whiffler '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Wild Rose '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Golden Plover '''USA''' * [[1867 Belmont Stakes|Belmont Stakes]] – [[Ruthless (horse)|Ruthless]]
==[[Lacrosse]]== '''Events''' * [[William George Beers]], a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[dentist]], rewrites the rules written by the [[Montreal Lacrosse Club]] in [[1856 in sports|1856]]. * First lacrosse game using Beers' rules is played at [[Upper Canada College]], who lose to the Toronto Cricket Club by a score of 3–1.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 13 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 24th [[The Boat Race 1867|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]] '''Other events''' * Four oarsmen from [[Saint John, New Brunswick]], Canada win the World Championship in Paris, becoming Canada's first world champions and earning the "[[Paris Crew]]" nickname.
==[[Rugby football]]== '''Events''' * Foundation of [[Wasps RFC]]

revision.text:
{{Year box}} '''1895 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Penn Quakers]] '''Events''' * 3 September – the earliest known [[professionalism|professional]] football game is played in [[Latrobe, Pennsylvania]] where Latrobe YMCA defeats the [[Jeannette, Pennsylvania|Jeannette Athletic Club]] 12–0.
==[[Association football]]== '''Belgium''' * Formation in [[Brussels]] of the [[Royal Belgian Football Association]] (Koninklijke Belgische Voetbalbond or KBVB) '''Brazil''' * [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]], officially founded in [[Rio de Janeiro]] on November 17.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Sunderland FC|Sunderland]] 47 points, [[Everton FC|Everton]] 42, [[Aston Villa]] 39, [[Preston North End]] 35, [[Blackburn Rovers]] 32, [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] 32 * [[1895 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Aston Villa]] 1–0 [[West Bromwich Albion]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London. This is the first time Crystal Palace is used as the venue for the final and it will stage all finals until 1914. * In the Football League, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] is relegated from Division One to Division Two and [[Bury FC|Bury]] is promoted. [[Walsall FC|Walsall]] is expelled from the league and replaced by [[Loughborough FC]] (league membership 1895–1900) * [[West Ham United]] founded as Thames Ironworks FC, a works team, by Arnold Hills who is a London shipyard owner. '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] * [[1895 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[St Bernard's F.C.|St Bernard's]] 2–1 [[Renton F.C.|Renton]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]] '''Switzerland''' * Formation of the [[Swiss Football Association]]. It is generally known by the abbreviation of ASF-SFV based on its name in three of the national languages of Switzerland. ASF stands for both French (Association Suisse de Football) and Italian (Associazione Svizzera di Football), while SFV is the German (Schweizerischer Fussballverbund). In the fourth national language of Switzerland, [[Romansh language|Romansh]], it is abbreviated as ASB (Associaziun Svizra da Ballape).
==[[Bandy]]== '''Events''' * Bandy is introduced to Sweden. The royal family, barons and diplomats are the earliest players.
==[[Baseball]]== '''National championship''' * [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] win the second of three successive [[National League]] championships '''Events''' * [[Temple Cup]] – [[Cleveland Spiders]] 4–1 [[Baltimore Orioles (19th century)|Baltimore Orioles]] * Veteran player [[Bud Fowler]] and the Page Woven Wire Fence Company organise the [[Page Fence Giants]], a black professional team touring out of [[Adrian, Michigan]]. Economic depression in the 1890s has eliminated all but the [[Cuban Giants]] in New York City and neighboring states.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] relinquishes the [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship in order to fight as a heavyweight (there is no light-heavyweight division yet).<ref name="BS">[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/fitz.htm Cyber Boxing Zone – Bob Fitzsimmons]. Retrieved on 14 November 2009.</ref> '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>{{cite web|title=Cyber Boxing Zone |url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5hg1si20f?url=http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm |archivedate=2009-06-20 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-06-20 |df= }}</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[James J. Corbett]] * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Bob Fitzsimmons]] → title vacant after Fitzsimmons relinquishes it * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Tommy Ryan]] * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – title vacant * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[George Dixon (boxer)|George Dixon]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Jimmy Barry]]
==[[Chess]]== '''Events''' * The [[Hastings 1895 chess tournament|Grand International Chess Congress]] is held in the summer at [[Hastings]] and is won by [[Harry Nelson Pillsbury]] ahead of [[Mikhail Chigorin]] and current [[chess world champion|world champion]] [[Emanuel Lasker]].
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[W G Grace]]'s "Indian Summer" in which he scores his 100th career century and becomes the first player to score 1000 first-class runs in a calendar month (i.e., May) * [[County Championship]] expands from 9 to 14 teams with the restoration of [[Derbyshire CCC|Derbyshire]] and [[Hampshire CCC|Hampshire]]; and the introduction of [[Essex CCC|Essex]], [[Leicestershire CCC|Leicestershire]] and [[Warwickshire CCC|Warwickshire]] * Inaugural [[Minor Counties Cricket Championship|Minor Counties Championship]] is held '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Surrey CCC|Surrey]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Durham County Cricket Club|Durham]], [[Norfolk County Cricket Club|Norfolk]] and [[Worcestershire CCC|Worcestershire]] share the title * Most runs – [[W G Grace]] 2346 @ 51.00 (HS 288) * Most wickets – [[Tom Richardson (cricketer)|Tom Richardson]] 290 @ 14.37 (BB 9–49) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year|Wisden Cricketer of the Year]] – [[WG Grace]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[Victoria cricket team|Victoria]] * Most runs – [[Albert Ward (cricketer, born 1865)|Albert Ward]] 916 @ 41.63 (HS 219) * Most wickets – [[George Giffen]] 93 @ 22.54 (BB 8–77) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Europeans cricket team|Europeans]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – [[Transvaal cricket team|Transvaal]] '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Guyana cricket team|British Guiana]]
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural [[1895 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] and [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] tournaments are held. '''Major tournaments''' * [[1895 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[John Henry Taylor]] * [[1895 U.S. Open (golf)|U.S. Open]] – [[Horace Rawlins]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Charles B. Macdonald]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1895 Grand National|Grand National]] – Wild Man From Borneo * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Galeottia (horse)|Galeottia]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Kirkconnel (horse)|Kirkconnel]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Sir Visto]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[La Sagesse (horse)|La Sagesse]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – Sir Visto '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Auraria '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Bonniefield '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Yellow Girl II * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Portmarnock '''USA''' * [[1895 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Halma * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Belmar * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Belmar
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * 9 March — [[Montreal Hockey Club]] defeats challenger [[Queen's Golden Gaels|Queen's University]] to retain the Stanley Cup * 9 March — by virtue of winning the [[1895 AHAC season]], the [[Montreal Victorias]] take over the Stanley Cup '''Other events''' * March — Queen's University defeats Trinity University 17–3 to win the [[Ontario Hockey Association]] title and the right to challenge for the Stanley Cup. * Halifax Stanleys and Dartmouth Jubilees play the first recorded game involving two all-black hockey teams leading to the formation of the [[Coloured Hockey League]] based in [[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]]. The league will feature teams from across Canada's [[Maritime Provinces]] and will operate until 1930.
==[[Motor racing]]== * The [[Paris–Bordeaux–Paris]] race is held and is the first real motor race as all competitors start together. The first to arrive is [[Émile Levassor]] in a two-cylinder {{convert|4|bhp|kW PS|lk=on|abbr=on}}<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> {{convert|1205|cc|cid|abbr=on}} [[Panhard-Levassor]]. He completes the course in 48 hours and 48 minutes,<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> finishing nearly six hours before the runner-up. Levassor's was disqualified, having only two seats, instead of the required four.<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> The official winner is [[Paul Koechlin]], the third to arrive, 11 hours after Levassor;<ref>{{cite news|title=Ces merveilleux fous roulants sur leurs drôles de machines|url=http://www.lefigaro.fr/reportage/20070709.FIG000000143_ces_merveilleux_fous_roulants_sur_leurs_droles_de_machines.html|accessdate=30 September 2011|newspaper=Le Figaro|date=9 July 2007|language=French}}</ref> he is awarded a [[French franc|Fr]]31,000 prize.<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> Among the other entrants was [[André Michelin]] in a [[Peugeot]], on his company's [[pneumatic tire]]s; he suffered numerous blowouts.<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> The race is in retrospect sometimes referred to as the ''I Grand Prix de l'ACF''.<ref>[http://www.teamdan.com/archive/gen/upto1903/1895.html 1895 Grand Prix and Paris Races]. Retrieved on 22 August 2009.</ref> The event proves cars and their drivers can travel very long distances in a reasonable time. It gives an enormous boost to the motor industry and the enthusiastic public interest in the event ensures the popularity of motor racing as a sport. *18 May, the first motor race in Italy is held. It is run on a course from [[Turin]] to [[Asti]] and back, a total of {{convert|93|km|mi|abbr=on}}. Five entrants started the event; only three completed it. It was won by [[Simone Federman]] in a four-seat [[Daimler-Motoren-Gesellschaft|Daimler]] [[Daimler Omnibus|Omnibus]], at an average speed of {{convert|15.5|km/h|mph|abbr=on}}.<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> *the [[Chicago Times|''Chicago Times Herald'']] sponsors a race; only two entrants arrive.<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> *24 September-3 October, the ''[[Automobile Club de France]]'' sponsors the longest race to date, a {{convert|1710|km|mi|abbr=on}} event, from [[Bordeaux]] to [[Agen]] and back.<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> Because it is held in ten stages, it can be considered the first [[Rallying|rally]]. The first three places are taken by a Panhard, a Panhard, and a three-wheeler [[De Dion-Bouton]].<ref>[http://www.grandprixhistory.org/story.htm Grand Prix History online] (retrieved 11 June 2017)</ref> * November – subsequently, several French motoring pioneers form the ''[[Automobile Club de France]]'' (ACF), which thereafter will govern most major races in France.
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 30 March – [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 52nd [[The Boat Race 1895|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby football]]== * 27 August – Twenty-one rugby clubs in the north of England split from the [[Rugby Football Union]] over the issue of broken time payments and form the [[Northern Rugby Football Union]], which is the forerunner of the [[Rugby Football League]]. In due course, two separate codes of rugby football develop: [[rugby union]], governed by the RFU; and [[rugby league]], governed by the Northern Union, which is subsequently called the [[Rugby Football League]] (RFL).
'''Union''' * 13th [[1895 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is won by [[Scotland national rugby union team|Scotland]]
'''League''' * The Northern Union establishes its [[Rugby Football League Championship|National Championship]], [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] and [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] competitions ahead of the inaugural 1895–96 season. * 7 September – inaugural [[1895–96 Northern Rugby Football Union season|rugby league season]] begins.
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1895 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Jaap Eden]] (Netherlands)
==[[Tennis]]== '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Wilfred Baddeley]] (GB) defeats [[Wilberforce Eaves]] (GB) 4–6 2–6 8–6 6–2 6–3 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Charlotte Cooper (tennis)|Charlotte Cooper Sterry]] (GB) defeats [[Helen Jackson (tennis)|Helen Jackson]] (GB) 7–5 8–6 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[André Vacherot]] defeats [[Laurent Riboulet]] 9–7 6–2 '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Fred Hovey]] defeats [[Robert Wrenn]] 6–3 6–2 6–4 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Juliette Atkinson]] defeats [[Helen Hellwig]] 6–4 6–2 6–1
==[[Volleyball]]== '''Events''' * 9 February – [[William G Morgan]] invents volleyball
==[[Yacht racing]]== '''America's Cup''' * The [[New York Yacht Club]] retains the [[America's Cup]] as ''[[Defender (1895 yacht)|Defender]]'' defeats British challenger ''[[Valkyrie III (yacht)|Valkyrie III]]'', of the [[Royal Yacht Squadron]], 3 races to 0. (''[[Valkyrie III (yacht)|Valkyrie III]]'' is disqualified in the second race and abandons the third.)
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1851 – 1900}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1895 in sports| ]]

revision.comment: /* [[Rugby league]] */clean up, replaced: [[Hunslet F.C. (1883)| → [[Hunslet R.L.F.C.| using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Year box}} [[Image:RobinsonThrowing.jpg|thumb|right|225px|1906 ''[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]'' photo of [[Bradbury Robinson|Brad Robinson]], who threw the first legal [[forward pass]] in [[American football]]]] '''1906 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Princeton Tigers football|Princeton Tigers]] and [[Yale Bulldogs football|Yale Bulldogs]] (shared) '''Events''' * 31 March — the Intercollegiate Athletic Association of the United States (IAAUS) is established to set rules for amateur [[sport]]s in the [[United States]], including revisions to [[American football]] rules that legalise the forward pass. The IAAUS later became the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) in 1910. * 5 September — [[Bradbury Robinson]] of [[St. Louis University]] throws the first legal [[forward pass]] to teammate [[Jack Schneider]] in a 22–0 victory over [[Carroll University|Carroll College]] in [[Waukesha, Wisconsin]]. * 25 October — [[Peggy Parratt]] of the [[Massillon Tigers]] throws the first legal forward pass in professional football to teammate [[Dan Policowski|Dan "Bullet" Riley]] in a 60–0 victory over a combined Benwood-Moundsville team in [[Massillon, Ohio]]. * 24 November — the [[Canton Bulldogs-Massillon Tigers Betting Scandal]] effectively ends the first era of major professional football. All three of the top three teams in the nation will fall by the wayside by 1907.
==[[Association football]]== '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] 51, [[Preston North End]] 47, [[Sheffield Wednesday|The Wednesday]] 44, [[Newcastle United]] 43, [[Manchester City]] 43, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 41 * [[1906 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Everton FC|Everton]] 1–0 [[Newcastle United]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[VfB Leipzig]] 2–1 [[Pforzheim]] at Nuremberg '''Mexico''' * [[C.D. Guadalajara|Club Unión]] founded (8 May). '''Portugal''' * [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]] founded (14 April). '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Glasgow Celtic|Celtic]] * [[1906 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup final]] – [[Heart of Midlothian F.C.|Hearts]] 1–0 [[Third Lanark A.C.|Third Lanark]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]] '''Spain''' * [[Deportivo de La Coruna]], officially founded in [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]], on March 2.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}}
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''VFL Premiership''' * [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] wins the 10th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership – Carlton 15.4 (94) d [[Fitzroy Football Club|Fitzroy]] 6.9 (45) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG) '''Events''' * The [[Australian National Football Council|Australasian Football Council]] is established in November to serve as the top-level governing body for Australian rules football in Australia and New Zealand.
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 9–14 October — [[Chicago White Sox]] (AL) defeats [[Chicago Cubs]] (NL) in the [[1906 World Series]] by 4 games to 2.
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 23 February — [[Marvin Hart]] loses his [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship to [[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]] over 20 rounds in [[Los Angeles]]. Burns holds the title until December 1908 and successfully defends it 11 times until he is defeated by [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]]. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Marvin Hart]] → [[Tommy Burns (boxer)|Tommy Burns]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – [[Tommy Ryan]] → vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – [[Barbados Joe Walcott]] → Billy "Honey" Mellody * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Battling Nelson]] → [[Joe Gans]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Abe Attell]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – Jimmy Walsh
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * [[George Hirst]] of [[Yorkshire CCC|Yorkshire]] and [[England national cricket team|England]] creates a unique record as the only player to score 2000 runs and take 200 wickets in the same season: 2385 runs and 208 wickets. * The [[Plunket Shield]] competition is introduced in New Zealand ahead of the 1906–07 season. The shield is donated by [[Lord Plunket|William Plunket, 5th Baron Plunket]], the [[Governor-general of New Zealand|Governor-general]] of New Zealand. In its early years, until 1920–21 when a league system is started, the competition is decided by a series of challenge matches between five provincial Cricket Association sides, [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]], [[Wellington cricket team|Wellington]], [[Canterbury cricket team|Canterbury]], [[Otago cricket team|Otago]] and, briefly, [[Hawke's Bay cricket team|Hawke's Bay]]. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Kent CCC|Kent]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – [[Staffordshire County Cricket Club|Staffordshire]] * Most runs – [[Tom Hayward]] 3518 @ 66.37 (HS 219) * Most wickets – [[George Hirst]] 208 @ 16.50 (BB 7–18) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – [[Jack Crawford (cricketer)|Jack Crawford]], [[Arthur Fielder]], [[Ernie Hayes]], [[Kenneth Hutchings]], [[Neville Knox]] '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[James Mackay (cricketer)|Jim Mackay]] 902 @ 112.75 (HS 203) * Most wickets – Leonard Garnsey 36 @ 21.44 (BB 6–48) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Presidency]] – [[Hindus cricket team|Hindus]] shared with [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – not contested '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[René Pottier]] (France) wins the 4th [[1906 Tour de France|Tour de France]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''Events''' * Inaugural [[International Skating Union|ISU]] World Championships for women is held at [[Davos]], Switzerland '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – [[Gilbert Fuchs]] (Germany) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – [[Madge Syers-Cave]] (Great Britain)
==[[Golf]]== '''Events''' * As scoring improves, [[Alex Smith (golfer)|Alex Smith]] becomes the first golfer in US Open history to break 300 for 72 holes when he posts 295 '''Major tournaments''' * [[1906 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[James Braid (golfer)|James Braid]] * [[1906 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[Alex Smith (golfer)|Alex Smith]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[James Robb (golfer)|James Robb]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Eben Byers]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1906 Grand National|Grand National]] – Ascetic's Silver * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Flair (horse)|Flair]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Gorgos]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – [[Spearmint (horse)|Spearmint]] * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Keystone II]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Troutbeck (horse)|Troutbeck]] '''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Poseidon '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Slaughter '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Brown Bess * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Killeagh '''USA''' * [[1906 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – Sir Huon * [[Preakness Stakes]] – Whimsical * [[Belmont Stakes]] – Burgomaster
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * February — [[Ottawa Senators (original)|Ottawa Hockey Club]] defeats [[Queen's Golden Gaels|Queen's College]] of [[Kingston, Ontario]] in a [[Stanley Cup]] challenge * March — Ottawa defeats [[Smiths Falls, Ontario]] two games to none in another Stanley Cup challenge. * March — Ottawa and [[Montreal Wanderers]] tie for first place in the ECAHA league's regular season with 9–1 records. The two clubs hold a playoff to determine the ECAHA and Stanley Cup champion. The Wanderers win the series for their first Stanley Cup win, defeating the ''Silver Seven'' in a two-game total-goals series. '''Other events''' * 3 January — the [[Eastern Canada Amateur Hockey Association]] (ECAHA) begins its [[1906 ECAHA season|inaugural season]] * [[Berlin, Ontario]] defeats the [[Argonaut Rowing Club|Toronto Argonaut Rowing Club]] to win the [[Ontario Hockey Association]] title.
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1906 in motorsport}}
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 7 April — [[Cambridge University Boat Club|Cambridge]] wins the 63rd [[The Boat Race 1906|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.|Bradford F.C.]] 5–0 [[Salford Red Devils|Salford]] at [[Headingley Rugby Stadium]], [[Leeds]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – ''not contested'' * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] 8–0 [[Leigh Centurions|Leigh]] (replay following 0–0) * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Hunslet R.L.F.C.|Hunslet]] 13–3 [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] '''Events''' * Rules of rugby league are changed so that the number of players in a team is reduced from 15 to 13,<ref>{{cite book |title= The best ever Australian Sports Writing |last= Cunneen |first= Chris |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= 2001 |publisher= Black Inc. |location= Australia |isbn= 1-86395-266-7 |page= 314 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=66OBschGE_YC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= 19 February 2011}}</ref> and following tackles the play-the-ball is introduced in place of rucks and mauls.<ref>{{cite web|title=The History Of Rugby League|url=http://www.napit.co.uk/viewus/infobank/rugby/superleague/history.php|work=Rugby League Information|publisher=napit.co.uk|accessdate=2 January 2014}}</ref>
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1906 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – ''none declared''
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Home Nations Championship''' * 24th [[1906 Home Nations Championship|Home Nations Championship]] series is shared by [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]] and [[Wales national rugby union team|Wales]]
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Anthony Wilding]] (NZ) defeats [[Francis Fisher]] (NZ) 6–0 6–4 6–4 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Laurence Doherty]] (GB) defeats [[Frank Riseley]] (GB) 6–4 4–6 6–2 6–3 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Dorothea Douglass Lambert Chambers]] defeats [[May Sutton Bundy]] 6–3 9–7 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Maurice Germot]] defeats [[Max Decugis]]: details unknown * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Kate Gillou|Kate Gillou-Fenwick]] defeats Mac Veagh: details unknown '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[William Clothier]] defeats [[Beals Wright]] 6–3 6–0 6–4 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Helen Homans]] defeats [[Maud Barger-Wallach]] 6–4 6–3 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1906 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|GBR|name=British Isles}} 5–0 {{davis|USA|1896}} at Warple Road (grass) [[London]], [[United Kingdom]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Sports by year 1901 – 1950}}
[[Category:Sports by year]] [[Category:1906 in sports| ]]

* [[2013 Trabzon Cup (1)]], which began on 2 September * [[2013 Trabzon Cup (2)]], which began on 9 September
