revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}}
The '''transfer window''' is the period during the year in which a [[football club]] can [[Transfer (association football)|transfer]] players from other playing staff into their playing staff. Such a transfer is completed by registering the player into the new club through FIFA. "Transfer window" is the unofficial term commonly used by the media for the concept of "registration period" as described in the FIFA Regulations on the Status and Transfer of Player.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/affederation/administration/regulations%5fon%5fthe%5fstatus%5fand%5ftransfer%5fof%5fplayers%5fen%5f33410.pdf |format=PDF |title=Regulations on the Status and Transfer of Players (2008) |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=23 January 2008 |date=19 October 2003 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080913151636/http://www.fifa.com/mm/document/affederation/administration/regulations_on_the_status_and_transfer_of_players_en_33410.pdf |archivedate=13 September 2008 }}</ref> According to the rules, each national football association decides on the time (such as the dates) of the 'window' but it may not exceed 12 weeks. The second registration period occurs during the season and may not exceed four weeks.
The transfer window of a given football association governs only international transfers into that football association. International transfers out of an association are always possible to those associations that have an open window. The transfer window of the association that the player is leaving does not have to be open.
The window was introduced in response to negotiations with the [[European Commission]]. The system has been used in many [[UEFA|European leagues]] before being brought into compulsory effect by [[FIFA]] during the [[2002–03 in English football|2002–03 season]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/1780263.stm|title=Uefa wants transfer windows|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 October 2008|date=24 January 2002}}</ref> English football was initially behind the plans when they were proposed in the early 1990s, in the hope that it would improve teams' stability and prevent agents from searching for deals all year around, but by the time it was eventually introduced they had to be persuaded that it would work.<ref>{{cite news |first1=John |last1=Ashdown |first2=Rob |last2=Smyth |title=Why does the Premier League have a January transfer window |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/feb/01/the-knowledge-premier-league-transfer-window |work=The Guardian |date=1 February 2012 |accessdate=12 April 2012}}</ref> However, the exact regulations and possible exceptions are established by each competition's governing body rather than by the national football association.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/NewsFromTheFA/Postings/2005/01|archive-url=https://archive.is/20071029052205/http://www.thefa.com/TheFA/NewsFromTheFA/Postings/2005/01|dead-url=yes|archive-date=29 October 2007|title=Transfer clarification|publisher=Football Association|accessdate=29 October 2008|date=1 April 2005}}</ref>
== Current schedules and exceptions ==
FIFA regulates in general that there shall be two windows, a longer one (max. twelve weeks) in the break between seasons and a shorter one (max. one month) in the middle of a season. The specific periods depend on the league's season cycle and are determined by the national football authorities.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/affederation/administration/regulations_on_the_status_and_transfer_of_players_en_33410.pdf|format=PDF|title=Regulations on the Status and Transfer of Players|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=29 October 2008|page=10}}</ref>
Most major European leagues commence in the second half of the year (e.g. August or September) and stretch over two calendar years to the first half of the next year (e.g. May), resulting in a close season window in the Summer ending in August, and a mid-season window in January.
The periods are different when a league runs throughout a single calendar year, as in most [[Nordic countries]] due to weather constraints, [[Major League Soccer]] due to both weather and competition from other locally popular sports (notably [[basketball]] and [[American football]]), or as the traditional season in the Southern Hemisphere. The first window generally opens from 1 March until midnight of 30 April, followed by the in-season window from 1 to 31 August.

TaskFleet|last=GmbH|publisher=|accessdate=15 February 2017}}</ref> |- | 1 December – 31 January | 1–30 June | Kenya<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.futaa.com/football/article/kenyan-transfers-to-be-heavily-scrutinised|title=Kenyan transfers to be heavily scrutinised|date=9 May 2012|accessdate=27 May 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705012155/http://www.futaa.com/football/article/kenyan-transfers-to-be-heavily-scrutinised|archivedate=5 July 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |- |}
[[Premier League clubs]] in England voted to end the summer window on the Thursday before the start of the season - on August 9 in 2018, instead of August 31. Because FIFA demands the window must be open for 12 weeks, the window will open around May 17, shortly after the final games of the season on May 13. Clubs will be able to sell players until August 31 but not buy replacements after the deadline of August 9.
Although, in England, transfers between clubs in the same league can take place as soon as the last competitive fixtures for the season have been played, many transfers will not be completed until 1 July because many players' contracts expire on 30 June. International transfers into the English leagues (including the Premier League) cannot be made until the window has opened on 17 May. Outside the transfer window, a club may still sign players on an emergency basis, usually if they have no goalkeeper available. Special dispensation from their competition's governing body, for example the Premier League, is required. The transfer window restriction does not apply to clubs in or below the [[National League (division)|National League division]].<ref name="auto"/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/mobile/football/13600908.stm | publisher=BBC News | title=Transfers – June 2011 | date=31 May 2011}}</ref>
If the last day of a transfer window is on a weekend, the deadline can be extended to the following Monday at the request of those involved for business reasons.<ref name="deadline_day_rules_and_regulations" /> The first shift of the deadline since its inception took place in summer 2008, when the deadline was extended by 24 hours to fall on Monday 1 September at midnight.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7568921.stm |title=Transfer deadline to be extended |date=18 August 2008 |work=BBC Sport |accessdate=7 October 2008 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5bOAGADJu?url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/7568921.stm |archivedate=7 October 2008 |df=dmy }} 7 October 2008</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/wenger-urges-fans-to-support-adebayor-as-striker-seals-new-deal-901913.html|author=Gatward, Matt|title=Wenger urges fans to support Adebayor as striker seals new deal|work= The Independent|date= 19 August 2008|location=London}}</ref> The transfer deadline in England was similarly extended to 5 pm 1 September 2009, due to the August Bank Holiday. The [[Deutsche Fußball Liga|German football league]] announced an extension of the January 2009 deadline to 2 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bundesliga.de/de/liga/news/2008/index.php?f=0000105068.php|title=Wechselperiode I endet erst am Montag|publisher=Bundesliga|accessdate=29 October 2008|date=29 August 2008|language=German}}</ref>
[[Free agent]]s can be signed by a club at any time during the season, if they had been released by their previous club before the end of the transfer window.<ref name="deadline_day_rules_and_regulations">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/6971785.stm|title=Deadline day rules & regulations|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 October 2008|date=1 September 2008}}</ref> A club can request to sign a player on emergency basis, e.g. if several [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeepers]] are injured at the same time.<ref name="deadline_day_rules_and_regulations" /> Outside the transfer window in [[Football in England|England]], once seven days have passed following the end of a transfer window, clubs from the [[English Football League]] (Regulation 53.3.4)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/global/section6.aspx#TQpEOrzdeJySOqaP.99|title=Section 6 - Players|first=The Football|last=League|publisher=|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> and (provided the player is not registered with a club from any league below the National League division) [[National League (division)|National League division]]<ref>http://footballconference.co.uk/uploads/docs/Rules.pdf</ref> (Rule 6.6.4) can loan in players i) in the first half of the season, until 5.00pm on the fourth Thursday in November and ii) in the second half of the season, until 5.00pm on the fourth Thursday in March. An existing [[loan (football)|loan deal]] can be made permanent at any time outside the transfer window.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.football-league.co.uk/global/section6.aspx |title= Section 6 - Players |publisher= The Football League |date=11 August 2014 |accessdate=3 February 2015}}</ref>
The day upon which a window closes is known as '''transfer deadline day''', and is usually one of the busiest days of the window, generating a flurry of transfers, often because a number of interdependent transfers are completed resembling a [[Chain (in selling a house)|housing chain]], generating much media interest.
== Calls to end the transfer window ==
[[Steve Coppell]], former manager of [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in England's [[Premier League]], and others have called for the transfer window to be scrapped in favour of the previous system, where deals could be struck throughout the season until the closing weeks.<ref>{{cite news | date=2 January 2008| url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/reading/article3120658.ece | title=Steve Coppell calls for end to transfer window | work=The Times | accessdate=2 January 2008 | location=London | first=Fiona | last=Hamilton}}</ref> Coppell said that the transfer window breeds panic and encourages "scurrilous" transfer activity adding that "I cannot see the logic in a transfer window. It brings on a fire-sale mentality, causes unrest via the media and means clubs buy too many players" adding that "The old system, where if you had a problem you could look at loans or make a short-term purchase, was far better than this system we have at the moment".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2287651/Managers-hit-out-at-rubbish-transfer-system.html |title=Managers hit out at 'rubbish' transfer system |publisher=The Telegraph |date=1 January 2008 |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> Former England Manager [[Sven-Göran Eriksson]] has also questioned the value of the transfer window, commenting: "You do wonder at times if it is right to have a window, it was easier when it was open all the time and perhaps fairer for the players. I am sure much of the business being done on the last day is a little bit desperate and that is not right. I think it was better before, but then I am old".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/story/0,19528,11095_7152349,00.html? |title=Sven wants windows scrapped |publisher=Sky Sports |date=5 September 2011 |accessdate=5 September 2011}}</ref>
In January 2013 [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] manager [[Arsène Wenger]] asked for the January transfer window to be limited to two transfers per window and claimed it is "unfair" in its current form. He cited [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] transfer activity as an example.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21193630 |title=Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger wants two-player transfer limit |work=BBC |date=25 January 2013 |accessdate=25 January 2013}}</ref> The following year, Wenger hit out at [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]'s £37m purchase of [[Juan Mata]] from rivals [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. Wenger argued that the transfer was unfair because United and Chelsea had already played each other twice during the season, but United would still have to play Arsenal, and said that "the rules should be adapted more for fairness".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/news/11661/9129436/arsene-wenger-thinks-juan-matas-proposed-transfer-to-man-utd-from-chelsea-is-unfair |title=Arsene Wenger thinks Juan Mata's proposed transfer to Man Utd from Chelsea is unfair |publisher=Sky Sports |date=24 January 2014 |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref> [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] manager [[Manuel Pellegrini]] backed the sentiment of Wenger, disagreeing that a player "can go from one team to another team in the same league at this part of the year" and also said that the winter transfer window was unbalanced in favour of big clubs, saying "a club with money can take the best players from the other teams".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/manuel-pellegrini-agrees-with-arsene-wenger--juan-mata-moving-from-chelsea-to-manchester-united-is-unfair-9083543.html |title=Manuel Pellegrini agrees with Arsene Wenger - Juan Mata moving from Chelsea to Manchester United is unfair |publisher=The Independent |date=24 January 2014 |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/10596136/Manchester-City-manager-Manuel-Pellegrini-backs-Arsenal-conterpart-Arsene-Wenger-over-Juan-Mata-transfer.html |title=Manchester City manager Manuel Pellegrini backs Arsenal conterpart Arsène Wenger over Juan Mata transfer |publisher=The Telegraph |date=24 January 2014 |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
Former [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] manager [[Alan Pardew]] questioned why the Premier League transfer window remains open after the start of the season after [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] made a bid for midfielder [[Yohan Cabaye]] during his time as [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] manager in August 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/23765521 |title=Alan Pardew unhappy at timing of Arsenal bid |publisher=BBC Sport |date=20 August 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2014}}</ref>
In January 2015, [[FIFPro]] said that the current transfer window system is "failing football and its players", one of the main issues being that players are released from clubs without explanation or compensation.<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31001193|title= Fifpro: players' union says 'failing' transfer system needs reform|date=27 January 2015|accessdate=27 January 2015 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
== See also ==

revision.text:
[[File:Viparita-Karani_Yoga-Asana_Nina-Mel.jpg|thumb|right|Viparita Karani]]
{{IndicText}}
'''Viparita Karani''' ({{lang-sa|विपरीतकरणी }}; {{IAST-hi1|viparītakaraṇī}}) literally '''Upside-Down''' is considered alternately as an [[asana]] or a [[mudra]] in haṭha yoga.
==Etymology== The name comes from the Sanskrit words ''viparita'' meaning "inverted" or "reversed", and ''karani'' meaning "doing" or "making".<ref> {{cite web | url = http://www.yogaartandscience.com/poses/inver/vipkar/vipkar.html | title = Witold Fitz-Simon - Viparita Karani | accessdate = 2011-07-29}}</ref>
==Description== Viparita Karani refers to any practice where one is upside down. This can include the asanas of shoulder stand ([[sarvangasana]]), headstand ([[sirsasana]]), or handstand ([[adho mukha vrksasana]]). In the [[hatha yoga pradipika]], as in most classical texts on haṭha yoga , viparita karani is listed as a mudra (HYP III.7), meaning its purpose is for the directing of energy or kundalini upwards within the body (HYP III.5) as opposed to asanas which are used in the Hatha Yoga Pradipika to create steadiness (HYP I.19).
In one popular expression of viparita karani as an asana in modern postural yoga, it resembles [[Salamba Sarvāngāsana]] (supported shoulder stand) but with [[flexion]] in the [[thoracic spine]] (rather than the [[cervical spine]], elbows on the floor and hands supporting hips or lower back.<ref name="Yoga Art">{{cite web|title=Viparita Karani Mudra (Upside Down Seal)|url=http://www.yogaartandscience.com/poses/inver/vkm/vkm.html|publisher=Yoga Art and Science|accessdate=21 August 2012}}</ref>
Variations include bringing the soles of the feet together such as in [[Baddha Konasana]] or letting the legs fall outward into a straddle.
==See also== *[[List of asanas]] *[[Hatha yoga]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Iyengar|first=B. K. S.|authorlink=B. K. S. Iyengar|title=Illustrated Light On Yoga|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pbx5AAAACAAJ|accessdate=9 April 2011|date=1 October 2005|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-81-7223-606-9}} *{{cite book|last=Saraswati|first=Swami Janakananda|authorlink=Swami Janakananda|title=Yoga, Tantra and Meditation in Daily Life|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FVLqCyTMFikC|accessdate=11 April 2011|date=1 February 1992|publisher=Weiser Books|isbn=978-0-87728-768-1}} *{{cite book|last=Saraswati|first=Swami Satyananda|authorlink=Swami Satyananda Saraswati|title=Asana Pranayama Mudra Bandha|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YpR1QgAACAAJ|accessdate=9 April 2011|date=1 August 2003|publisher=Nesma Books India|isbn=978-81-86336-14-4}} *{{cite book|last=Saraswati|first=Swami Satyananda|authorlink=Swami Satyananda Saraswati|title=A Systematic Course in the Ancient Tantric Techniques of Yoga and Kriya|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eWOrAAAACAAJ|accessdate=9 April 2011|date=January 2004|publisher=Nesma Books India|isbn=978-81-85787-08-4}}
